utterances: The images in Mitchell's New York exhibition are, in part, a response to U.S.
wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
One triptych juxtaposes washed out images of the U.S.
Capitol dome, the toppling of Saddam Hussein's statue in Baghdad, and a group of U.S.
senators.
You know, I thought, why don't they learn from history?
I mean, didn't they notice Russia went broke in Afghanistan?
I mean, you can't beat these people on their own turf, you know?
The whole thing is stupid.
They don't - they just aren't observant.
The show is in one way a departure for Mitchell.
While much of her previous visual art has been painting and drawing, these works are modified photographs taken with disposable cameras.
But in another way, it isn't.
Mitchell has always been known for her political and social concerns.
For nearly a decade, Mitchell had resisted the urge to write songs expressing her political feelings.
In fact, she says, she didn't write any music or even touch her piano or guitar.
One of the things that made me quit was I said I'm not going to write any more social commentary.
I'm not going to write this.
I just went, no. I just got stubborn with myself.
No more, because, you know, I took a lot of flack and I just thought that I didn't want to go through the experience.
I was mad at America.
And I thought, you know, come on.
Wake up, you know?
like wake them, shake them.
But I didn't want to be the one.
But ultimately, she couldn't fight what was inside.
(Soundbite of song ""Strong and Wrong"")
(Singing) Strong and wrong you win.
Only because that's the way it's always been.
Men love war!
That's what history's for.
History.
A mass-murder mystery.
His story.
Strong and wrong.
You lose everything.
Joni Mitchell wrote all of the lyrics for the songs on her new recording save one.
It's called ""If."" Her musical setting of a poem by Rudyard Kipling.
If you can keep your head while all about you, by losing theirs and blaming you.
If you can trust yourself when everybody doubts youâ€¦
(Soundbite of song ""If"")
(Singing) When everybody doubts you.
And make allowance for their doubting, too.
If you can wait and not get tired of waiting.
And when lied about it, stand tall don't deal in lies.
And when hated, don't give in to hating back.
Don't need to look so good.
Don't need to talk too wise.
Kipling's poem portrays a father giving advice to his son.
Mitchell kept most of the poem but made some changes.
She doesn't like Kipling's advice at the end.
Basically, what he tells the boy in the last stanza is: If you can endure, you'll inherit the Earth.
And I thought that's not what makes you inherit the Earth.
So how do you inherit the Earth?
By being awake.
And Joni Mitchell is back with the alarm clock.
For NPR News, I'm Reese Erlich.
You can see a slideshow of Joni Mitchell's new artwork on display in New York.
And hear songs from her new CD at npr.org.
Now, questions in 2007 about prewar reading in 2002.
In two presidential debates this week, CNN's Wolf Blitzer has asked about the prewar national intelligence estimate on Iraq.
Who read it?
A new book about Hillary Clinton says she did not read it.
On Sunday, in a Democratic debate, Blitzer asked Clinton whether she regretted not having read it and she said she didn't.
I think local governments can't necessarily stop ICE officers from doing anything.
What they can do is not assist ICE officers.
And there's a number of ways in which local law enforcement, local counties, local law officials can do.

One of the things is not to honor detainers when ICE asks local law enforcement to hold a noncitizen past the time of which they're allowed to hold the person in order for ICE or Immigration officials to get to the person and detain them.
The resistance can come in the form of not giving information, not helping, not using resources to ensnare noncitizens into the immigration and criminal system.
But clearly, that depends on the politics of any given city.
Yeah.
I mean, we have this thing called - you know, you hear about it all the time - the sanctuary cities, sanctuary counties, sanctuary states.
There's hundreds of counties, dozens of cities and a few states that have a different spectrum of the ways in which they're not complying or I guess not helping the federal government do its job.
Can you explain what will happen next for families if they're caught up in this weekend's raids?
I think it's a difficult thing.
What will likely happen is they would be put into detention.
They would have to either defend the deportation or come up with some sort of relief from the removal itself.
There's many forms of relief from removal - cancellation of removal, asylum, withholding of removal.
Or they have to somehow fight the reason they're in detention, which is very difficult to do without an attorney.
Aren't you all slammed already?
Yeah.
So in terms of - so that's sort of the second aspect, right, is in terms of actual representation.
I think immigration attorneys historically have been operating at full capacity.

And now if it even makes sense to say that you're beyond full capacity, I think one of the problems with the immigration system is that an immigrant doesn't have a guaranteed right to counsel the way that they do in criminal court.
That's Hemanth Gundavaram of Northeastern University.
Thank you for joining us.
Thank you very much.
Banks have been collapsing or disappearing into other banks at a rapid pace and we now have a few enormous banks.
Is that good or bad for consumers, here to answer that question is Jean Ann Fox.
She's Director of Financial Services at the Consumer Federation of America.
And Ms. Fox what does all this mean, this consolidation for the average depositor?
Well, it means that the bank you've been used to doing business with may no longer exist and competition for banking services may be reduced.

The impact on a particular product or service depends on which banks have merged, then put products the disappearing bank offered - but it is a good time for consumers to pay close attention to their bank accounts.
So what should they be looking for?
Well, first of all, they need to be sure they don't have more money in one particular bank than the FDIC insurance covers.
You know, basically that's $100,000 in an individual account.
But beyond that we need to pay attention to changes that can take place in bank accounts as banks adjust to the market.
Because under the account agreements that we sign when we open our checking accounts, generally the banks reserve the right to make any change, as long as they give you some form of notice about it.
So we have to pay attention to the boring fine print that comes in the bank account statement or notices that are posted on our online bank account.
In general, looking at recent history is it better or worse to be with a gigantic bank?
Generally you get a better deal with smaller community banks or with credit unions on fees.
A few years ago CFA did a report on the biggest banks overdraft and bounced checks fees.
And in 2005 the largest ten banks were charging a little over $30 for each time they let a customer overdraw their bank account.
That fee this year has gone up to an average of $34.65, so that's over a $4 jump in just three years on that one fee.
Generally, the largest banks charge the highest fees.
What kind of fees are we seeing now, besides the overdraft protection fees?
Well, banks also charge if they reject a transaction that overdraws your account.
We call that bounced check fee, they charge if you use an ATM when you're not one of their customers.
They charge if you deposit something that turns out to bounce, getting an extra bank statement, all the other services that you might ask for.
It's hard for consumer to get that information when they are out shopping for a bank account, although the Truth in Savings Act requires that banks make account information available to consumers.
Studies by the government accountability office and others have indicated that it's sometimes hard to get your hands on detailed information before you open a checking account.
With these fewer banks and bigger banks, does that mean less competition?
And does less competition mean a worse deal for consumers?
Well, definitely there will be fewer of the very largest banks.
But there's still thousands of community banks and credit unions around the country.
Anytime there's a big change in the banking industry, it's a good time for consumers to go re-shop the market, and see if you can get a better deal at lower cost, at a smaller bank.
Just because we've got these great big banks with their huge ATM networks doesn't necessarily mean they're the best deal for everybody.
Jean Ann Fox is Director of Financial Services at the Consumer Federation of America.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
From NPR News, this is Day to Day.
You are paying a lot for gas, who do you blame?
Do you blame oil companies?
Well, they know it and they are trying to change your mind with a multimillion dollar campaign.
Joining us now is Marketplace's John Dimsdale, and John, what is the goal of this campaign?
He's going to investigate who are the people who are leaking this information to us and to the press.
All right.
So what are the automakers proposing in this bid to get a truce?
Well, this is not going to stop just by taking out the few guys who managed to escape since Paris or after Brussels.
If we look at the complexity of the network and the fact that everywhere we can see more individuals linked to Abdelhamid Abaaoud, it's like a spider web.
Every single point in the spider's web is connected in one way to Abdelhamid Abaaoud.
It's not like they were confined cells - a cell that operated in France and a cell that operated in Brussels.
No, these guys were interconnected.
And I do believe, possibly, dozens more might have been involved in that particular network.
And that we probably only know half about it.
Pieter Van Ostaeyen speaking with us from Belgium.
We talked via Skype.
Pieter, thank you very much.
Thanks for having me.
Mona Haydar is an American Muslim.
And she wants to talk about it, so much so that she set up a stand outside a library in Cambridge, Mass.
with a big sign reading, ask a Muslim.
Along with the conversation, she offered free coffee and donuts.
Mona Haydar joins us on the line.
Welcome.
Thank you.
How did you get this idea?
Well, my husband was inspired one evening.
His name is Sebastian.
And we were just hanging out, eating dinner.
And he was like, what if we did something kind of crazy?
And he had seen this segment on This American Life where a young Iraqi man had done Asking An Iraqi.
And so he was like, why haven't we thought of this before?
Why don't we go out and to talk to people?
So we did it.
